While previous syllabries were of the form 610=60 or 512+x this schema is 5*16=120+x at its core
Where x denotes a devine extra row of vowels. See Elamite and Linear-B.

Anatolian Hieroglyphs sorted:
𔐀𔐁𔐂𔐃𔐄𔐅𔐆𔐇𔐈𔐉𔙀𔐊𔐋𔐌𔐍𔐎𔐏𔐐𔐕𔐖𔐗𔐘𔐓𔐔𔐚𔐛 𔑏𔑐𔑑𔑒𔑓𔑔𔑕𔗾𔑗
𔐜𔐝𔐞𔐟𔐠𔐡𔐢𔐣𔐤𔐥𔐦𔐧𔐨𔐩𔐪𔐫𔕲𔐬𔐭𔐮𔐯𔐰𔐱𔐲𔐳𔐴𔐵𔐶𔐷𔐸𔐹𔐺𔐻𔐼𔐽𔐾𔐿𔑀𔑁𔑂𔑃𔑄𔑅𔑆𔑇𔑈𔑉𔑊𔑋𔔷𔑌𔑍𔑎𔘢
𔑚𔑛𔑜𔑝𔑞𔑟𔑠𔑡𔑢𔑣𔑚𔑤𔑥𔑦𔑧𔑨𔑩𔔬 𔗧𔓊𔓋𔓌𔓍𔙅𔔸 𔙄 𔑙𔕕𔕉𔒗 𔘵𔘶𔘺
𔑪𔑫𔑬𔑭𔑮𔑯𔑰𔑱𔑲𔑳𔑴𔑵𔑶𔑷𔑸𔑹𔑺𔑻𔑼𔑽𔑾𔑿𔒀𔒁𔒂𔒃𔒄𔒅𔒆𔒇𔒈𔒉𔒊𔒋𔒌𔒍𔒎𔒏𔙃𔒐𔒑𔒒𔒓𔒔𔒤𔒕𔒖𔒗 𔒘 𔑖 𔓇 𔘝 𔘞
𔓢𔓣𔓙𔕴𔓭𔒙𔒚𔒛𔒜𔒝𔒞𔒟𔒠𔒡𔘩 𔒥𔒦𔒧𔒫 𔘋𔘌𔘳𔘐𔘑𔘻𔗱 𔒬𔒭𔒮𔒯𔒰𔖗𔓛𔒱𔒲𔒳𔒴𔒵𔒶𔒷𔒸𔒹𔒺𔒻𔒼𔒽𔓉 𔕩𔕪𔕬𔕫𔕭
𔒾𔒿𔘣𔓁𔓖𔓀𔓂𔓆𔓈𔔳𔔴𔔵𔔶𔓅𔑒𔖩𔖪𔖨𔗦𔗷𔗸𔗨𔗩𔗪𔗫𔗬𔗰𔗳𔘜𔔯𔘓𔗴𔕱𔕰 𔗵𔓟𔓠𔓡𔘏 𔕥𔕨𔓉𔖡𔖥𔖦𔖧𔑓𔓸𔓹𔘎𔓺𔓻𔓼𔓽𔘻𔘼𔘾𔘤𔘥𔘦𔘧𔘨
𔘂𔗽𔗹𔗼𔘄𔘃𔘰𔓃𔕰𔕶𔕞𔕱 𔕗𔖡𓋹𔕴𔓙 𔕊𔕋𔕌𔕍𔕎 𔕧𔓜𔕦𔗮𔗯𔓝𔓞𔙁𔕒𔗒𔗓𔗔𔖙𔖚𔖛𔖜𔘟𔘠𔘡𔕒𔕓 𔘕𔖋𔕞𔕱𔕶𔕵𔕖𔕗𔕙
𔓓𔓔𔓑𔓒𔐙𔘚𔓚𔓘𔘒𔔁𔔀𔓿𔓾𔗺𔓕𔓗𔓶𔓷𔖘𔗲𔑘𔗆𔘷𔗇𔙂𔖖𔕆𔕇𔕈𔕳𔓎𔓏𔓐𔕣𔕤𔕃 𔗋𔗎𔗏𔗐𔗑𔗘𔗙𔗚𔗛𔗜𔗝𔗠𔗡𔗢𔘒
𔗕𔖢𔗖𔗭𔗗𔐑𔐒𔓬𔓮𔓲𔓯𔓰𔓱𔔂𔔃𔔄𔔅𔔆𔔇𔔈𔔉𔔊𔔋𔔌𔔍𔔎𔔏𔔐𔔑𔔒𔔓𔔔𔓪𔓫𔔭𔔮𔕅𔕏𔘇𔘈𔔥𔘉𔘊
𔔼𔔽𔔕𔔖𔔗𔔘𔔙𔔚𔔛𔔜𔔝𔔞𔔟𔔠𔔡𔔢𔔣𔔤≠𔗟𔗞𔔦𔔧𔘍𔘛𔖐𔔨𔔥𔓄𔓨𔔩𔗣𔗤𔗥𔘫𔔪 𔓤 𔓩𔓥𔓦𔓧𔙆𔓳𔓴𔓵𔒪𔒩𔕑𔕐𔘔𔘖

we := wai: = wa/wi -𔗬𔖪𔗔 -wazasa -usos

a is an often optional vowel!
𔗷 •ma often connects to previous and deletes the following vowel …𔗷𔐤 ana/øna => /n/ /an/ /on/ /en/ !

Rhoterized syllables "𔖲" r are mostely ommitted from unicode

Luwian hieroglyphs "luwili" ≠ LINEAR-A

Anatolian hieroglyphs are an indigenous logographic script native to central Anatolia, consisting of some 500 signs. They were once commonly known as Hittite hieroglyphs, but the language they encode proved to be Luwian, not Hittite. They are typologically similar to Egyptian hieroglyphs, but they are not known to have played the sacred role of hieroglyphs in Egypt. There is no demonstrable connection to Hittite cuneiform.

bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment

Earliest development within a bilingual Hittite-Luwian environment. For example, the sign which has the form of a "taking" or "grasping" hand has the value /ta/, which is precisely the Hittite word ta-/da- "to take," in contrast with the Luwian cognate of the same meaning which is la-.

The first inscriptions confirmed as Luwian date to the Late Bronze Age, ca. 14th to 13th centuries BC.

After some two centuries of sparse material, the hieroglyphs resume in the Early Iron Age, ca. 10th to 8th centuries BC. In the early 7th century BC, the Luwian hieroglyphic script, by then aged some 700 years, was marginalized by competing alphabetic scripts and fell into oblivion.

Distribution centered around Neša/Kanesh-Purushanda/Tarsos with whole Anatolia prolly as perifery

Neša gave rise to nešili aka Hittite.

nuwaʿum ⋍ Luwian

𒉡𒉿 𒉢𒉿 ?

The Assyrian colonists and traders who were present in Anatolia at this time refer to the local people as nuwaʿum without any differentiation.

𔐱𔕬𔗬𔑰𔖱 FILIA tú-wa-ta-r "daughter" 𒁺𒌓𒋻𒊑𒄿𒀀𒋾𒅖 (duttariyatis)

Contemporary and colocal with Luwian cuneiform and (linguistically-related) Hittite cuneiform!!!
Luwian was probably spoken over a larger geographic region than Hittite.[1] Also see Palaic

K

𔗜 ku 𒆠 ki "que" and 𒌋 𒅇
𔔓 ki₄ 𓉪 𓉫 court house 𓊖 𓉔 √kar/cobra
𔗧 ka/ga ≠ 𔓊 𔔕 𔘵 𔕠 zí
𔐾 ka₂/ká 𓌨 katá 𔐾𔐞 ká.tá 𔐽𔐞 nì.dá •nieder 𔐽 𒉡 𒉌 NI / NU 𓂜 𓌨 ⋍ 𒉌 ⇔ knee?

L

𔓊 la₁ ⋍ ◁ 𔕟 𔖓 with 𔖱 form 𔑎 ⇔ 𔖔 ta 𔖕 𔘢 li ⇔ 𔔹 𔔺 𓌫
𔓊 la₁ langue 𔓊𔓋𔓌𔓍𔙅𔔸 tongue ⇔ 𔐖 #LOQUI speak talk

𔔹 li₁ ⋍ ri 𔔹𔖱
𔔹 li₁ ⋍ 𓅱𓅪𓅨 woeful in adjectives ? ⇔ 𓅂𔗷𔓯 -ty ?

𔔹 li₁ ⋍ 𔔺 •leafs 𔔹 𔘘 𔘗𔘗 𓆄𓆄 𓇋𓇋 LL ʎu > yu

𔗽 laₓ 𐘙 le 𐀩 re 𔗹 hur (feminine Gender)

M

𔗷 a 𓂝 a अस aṃs 𔗷 𐀖 mi 𔗸 arm ⋍ 𓂟 manu
𔘅 /ma2?/ @Payne ≠ 𔖎/𔘸/𔘺 pa ?
𔒅 ma ⋍ mäh 𐘋 ME mäh 𐀘 mu 𐘕 MU muh even in orthography!! ⇔ 𐠖 mi 𐘒 MI 𐘏 Kuh

P B PH V W

𔓐 paₓ paⁿ #PANIS (not used as syllable?)
𔕹 => 𔕷 𔖈 pa / 𔕹 zá pot ≠ 𔕮 sa5 (unicode lacks laddered narrow 𔕹 for pa CONFUSION!)
𔕷 𔖈 pa ≠ hú 𔖈 heart 𔖃 cœur 𔖂 zi za zarza COR •čarča
𔕷 pa ≠ hú 𔖈 •Henkel-pot
𔕷 pa pot "but" 𔖄 ⋍ 𔕾 PITHOS 𔔣 𔔤≠𔗟 𓊪 p 𔔢 𔔥 𔔦 𐎔 𔖳 𔑉 (some scripts with edgy ones ⇔ 𔔣 )
𔕷 pa L334 ≠ 𔕻 𔖂 𔖃 zi za COR heart L341 𔖪𔖱𔖪 za-r-za 𒍝𒀀𒅈𒍝 ≠ 𔕹 zá 𔕮 sa₅ seal 𔖌
𔖎/𔘸/𔘺 pa ≠ 𔘅 /ma/ @Payne ƒƒƒ 𔘅 ok 𔘺 almost in other source 𔘺 ≠ 𔘄 𔘸 𔔣 ≠ 𔖧 𔔼 𔓸 𔑛 𔑓
𔕯 pu pot ⇔ 𔖎 pa (also 𔕯 stripes on other side) ⇔ 𔖈 pa 𔕹 pa ≠ 𔖆 𔖇
𔑈 pi 𔑉 pai- pijama pipišša pay! "give" ⇔ 𔘅 𔑇 #ponere put gepay>gebe
𔑉 pi 𐘂 PA 𔖳 paw 𔑈 𔑇 𔐪𔖳 𔑅 𔖳 bi ≠ 𔐫 ta take!

W => V => PH

𔗬 wa/wiᵒ 𓊪𓍢 who •po 𐠡 po 𐘊 PO 𐀡 po 𐤐 pe հ ⋍ ף 𒉿 PI bì wey > yey ⴻ ə ه 𔘢 𔗬𔖱 ligature •pro ⵓ u w و ۉ yu

𔓁 wà/wìʳ 𔓖 •part 𔖳 ⇔ 𔓂 wohn/bau 𓆤 Wabe/web 𔓁 ?

𔗷 A/ʰE/•V vνn 𓆑 "he" !

Q

𔘰 hwi/hwaʳ 𔘄𔖭 qu ⋍ 𔕱 ⋍ 𐀹 ᶜwi CURRERE ʰwalk / run 𔑥 𔕃 𔑤

R 𔖱 𔖲 𔖭 𔖮 𔖰 𓎫 𓂋

𔖱 𔖲 ra 𔖭 𔖮 𔖰 ri •rise 𐀪 ri 人 rén ⇔ 𔗑 ru 1ˢᵗ erˢᵗ erst prosto pros proto first fraction 𔖱 ⅟ ½ ⅓ ⅔ ¼ 1/r
𔖭 -er ≠ 𔖮 -us -os -sa₈ UNUS suffix -man(s) ⇔ 𔖰 MINUS
𔖭 ra •erase 𔖰 MINUS 𔖮 -sans (⇔ 𔖕 vacant 𔔚 destroy …)
𔗳⋍ri vs ci
𔗑 ru 𓇳 ra round
𔑵 ru₂/rú :
𔑳 ru₂/rú rog roh рог *rágas "antler" ramuro ⇔ 鹿角 lùjiǎo
𔑴 ru₂/rú roe(deer) Reh(bock) Hirsch ⇔ *raihą PIE √rey- “spotted, streaked” ≠ *hrugną

S

𔗔 sa₁ shoot,seal,stopf,schopf 𔗩𔘥 ₛhair 𔗒 hi 𔗓 hi 𔗔⇔𓐮𓌓𓌔𓉻𓄝 𔗔 c
𔗦 sa₂/sá ⋍ 𔑒 ⋍ 𔓉 𔗮 si 𔗯 #zwie 𔗦 𐙆 TWE 2 zwirn/twist/…?
𔑷 sa₃/sà •šaph 𔑷𔑶𔑸𔑹 Schaf #CAPRA ƒ?
𔑷 sa₃/sàⁿ 𔑂 𔐨 𐀮 seⁿ ˢhand ( recognizable in some forms) !! 𔑷 𔖌 𔘤 … many scribal variants!
𔗆 sa₄ sun disk/tray ⵙ yaSun s س @Tifinagh 𓊃𓅱𓇳 Śara ⇔ 𔗑 ru 𓇳 ra ⇔ 𔗵 sù shine
𔕮 sa₅ seal! 𔗾 sí 𔕻 zì/zi₃ sarap OK ==
𔔀 sa₆ •street 𔓾 #VIA 𔕑 ia 𔓿 road 𔗅
𔕣 sa₇ şar 𔕆 kur шагьар 𔕤 šahar 𓊖 kur •city/court ⇔ 𔗆 sa₄ 𔗑 ru uruk (𔕣⋍𓊖 L316 @Payne missing in unicode!)
𔖮 -sa₈ -us -os suffix -man(s) ⇔ 𔖮 -sans 𔖰 MINUS ⇔ 𔖭 -er
𔖫 𓋴 staff •se- ge- s/ǧ 𔖫 𔐤 𔑣 𔓯 "see" na-ti-i naẓar 𓈖 𓍇 𓏌 𓁹 vision < besehen ≠ boustrophedon

𔓉 si ⋍ 𔓉 śa/sá ≠ 𔗦 sá/sa₂
𔗾 si₂/sí Siel 𔕮 sa₅ sír:4 •sym? 𔗾 meander 𔖻𔓴 Mündung <<<
𔖎? śi 𔕻 zì/zi₃ 𔘸 𔖨 #IUDEX judge ⇔ 𔕻𔖂𔖈𔖆 ⋍ 𔕹 zá
𔖎? ⇔ 𔖣 𔖤 /tarai/ DOM IUDEX IUSTITIA ⇔ Tyrant sultan

𔕷 __ why would it be sa? 𔕷 pa ??? 𔖂𔖈 ≠ 𔕮 sa₅ seal 𔕹 zá frequent syllable!

T=D series vs T=Z(ts/δ) vs Z⋍TH series

𔑰 ta₁/te Tier/tête ⋍ 𔑰 de donkey < 𔑯𔑱𔑲 te tête
𔐞 ta₂/tá ti / di 𓂞 "bone" with 𔖢 ⋍ 𔘩𔙂 ⇔
𔐫 ta₃/tà take 𔐫⋍𔐬 A41, A41b
𔐬 ta₃/tà take 𔐫 ⇔ 𔐬 turn tornado?
𔕦 ta₄/tu ⋍ zu (=tsu) 𔕦 (zu vs open ends OK)
𔓇 ta₅/ta/ti₅ 𒋰𒉺𒀀𒉌𒅖 /tappānis/ toupee @ top 𓁶 Tolle 𓁸 θρίξ ☑ lá/lí/za lock <?> 𔐬 za Zopf zwirbel
𔑛 ta₆ π.ta poda ⇔ 𔑣 ti ⇔ 𔑢 tu 𒉺𒋫𒀀𒀸 patās

𔑣 ti/tá/ta/da/di tur тур@NE-Caucasian 𔑛 ta₆ 𔑢 tu 𔑣 ti 𔘮 stiefel ⋍ (open or not)
𔘟 ti₂/tí/ti₄ ⋍ 𔕦𐀩 tu.re •Tier 𓄛 leather vs 𔕭
𔙄 ti₃/tì #kneel nieder 𔑝 𔙄 na.tief

𔑢 tu ⇔ 𓊌 таш dash ⇔ 𔖓 DIES days 𔖔 𔖕
𔑢 tu ⋍ 𔑛 ta₆ •thighs vs yad 𔑢 𔖔 𔖕 𔖓 𔙆 𔑅 𔘢 𔐪 ≠ 𔓊 𔕟 la
𔕬 tu₂/tú •Tuch 𔕪 tex 𔕫 𔕩 !!
𔕭 tu₃/tù ⋍ 𐘇 𐛃 𐀯 << 𔕭 tù #SCRIBA scribe/clerk
𔕦 tu/ta₄ ⋍ zu (=tsu) 𔕦 (zu vs open ends OK) 𔕦 tu ⋍ 𔘟 ti₄
𔔈 tu² 𓈋 𓈇 tawi ظوحي tawahi ≠ town 𓊕 𔔆 #REGIO kingdom 𔐑-tum 𔔇 tooth

𔐬 tà ≈ 𔐞 tá 𔐫 tà 𓂧 da 𐀅 hänDe

𔐨+𔔂=𔐹 ⇔ 𔐩
𔐱+𔐑=𔐳
𔐴+𔐒=𔐲

𔘓 𔗴 𔕱 𔘠 𔘟 𔘡 ?
𔑑𔐚 = 𔗴𔐚 # VERSUS toward (also as ligature?) /niₓ/ ante

changing the sound values is not unprecedented:
𔖩 zi •δi 𐠯 di 𔓫 was thought to be "i"
𔓱 ia was thought to be nasal ĩ/ã ⇔ ten 𔗐 ní

# cuneiform https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luwian_language#Cuneiform_Luwian

Compared to cuneiform Hittite, logograms are rare. Instead, most writing is done with the syllabic characters. A striking feature is the consistent use of 'full-writing' to indicate long vowels, even at the beginning of words. In this system a long vowel is indicated by writing it twice. For example, īdi "he goes" is written i-i-ti rather than i-ti, and ānda "in" is written a-an-ta rather than an-ta.

Lycian alphabet, almost roman but some insights!

𔖪𔖱𔖪 za-r-za 𒍝𒀀𒅈𒍝 {UZU}zārza heart PIE √ḱḗr.

Luwian (cuneiform, Hieroglyphic and Latin):

alphabetic-change

The whole Vowel series is doubtful and likely had consonant values or connotations

In Luwian / Anatolian :
𒄿__ ᵍi- (to go) [IE *ei- (to go)] ir,jir,gir 𒄿
𒄿__ ᵍimmari- (a field, steppe) [Hittite gimmara-] 𒄿𒆳 mar,mat 𒂔 <<?
𒄿__ ᵍipala- (left) [Hittite *gippala-] 𒄿 𒆎 KAB, GAB2, GUB3, ḪUB2 = left 𒄸 𒆏
𒄿__ ᵍišarwili (right) [cf. iššari-] 𒄿
𒄿__ ᵍiššari- (a hand) [IE *g'hesro- (a hand), CA *khesro- (a hand)] 𒄿
𒄿__ ᵍišta- (to stand) [IE *stá- (to stand), CA *sta- (to stand)] Gesteh! 𒄿

Grammar

𔗷 A 𔓯 I …
𔓯 obligatory -i- mutation between noun stem and case ending in nominative and accusative ( A-stems delete their vowel)
𔓯 I -y adjective mighty tati⇔dady…
__ -iya adjective
__ -ant participle
__ -want provision "full of"
__ -ali al… …al "of" "belonging to" irhalai frontier-post(?) ⇔ adverbial genial 𔔹𔓯 𔗲𔓯 𔒗𔓯
Since 𔗔 sa and 𔓉 si are monovalent, does isa/isi mean 𔓯𔗔 / 𔓯𔓉 ?
𔓯𔓉 -isi -is -es 's … Hauses … possessive (adjective) 𔓯𔓉𔗔 i-si-sa
𔓯𔗔 -isa -is -es 's possessive (adjective) 𔓯𔓉𔗔 i-si-sa
𔗷𔓉 -asi -as -os -us Ramonas possessive (adjective)
𔗷𔗔 -asa -as -os -us famous,famosa (possessive) adjective (having fame)

-ša/-za marks neuter nominative-accusative singular, contra Starke
-a Nominative-accusative forms in -a beside animate singulars in -iš/in are collectives

Suffixes
-ant habitant militant observant ⇔ 𓌙 tian
-(a)ma/i- (single m): lalama/i- 'receipt' < lala- 'take' animate nouns, Hittite deverbative -(i)ma-.
-a(i)mma/i- ma plasma dogma drama (Greek) ⇔
-ma-an -ma-an -[men](men.html) -[ment](ment.html) 𓄣 āḫra- 'ache' => āḫramman- 'state of pain/woe' -ttn [tion](tion.html) 𓏛 𓏤 nation (PIE) ⇔ -ttar 𓏛 𓏥 barter … ⇔ -s(t)ra/i-/ contra Starke -štar -aḫit -ahit …-heit (Germanic)

articles

…"who" bound suffix by convention:
𔕷𔗬 ⋍ 𔔣𓊪𓍢𓊪 > 𓊪𓍢 "who" (subject indicator "(it is) he, the one (who,which)"…)
𔕷𔗬 #pawa ⋍ 𓊪 𓅮 𓄿 | this, that | •pava
𔕷𔗬 #pawa ⇔ 𓃀 𓍢 𓇩 bawa bw bu (prefix)
𔗷𔕷 #apa [IE *ebho- (that), Hittite, Palaic apa-] ⇔ epi?
𔖪𔕷𔗬 ce… cette… this… that… (one/who)
𔖪𔕷𔗬 zapawa

𔒅 ma ⇔ 𓅓 Gerund in… -ing 𔗔𔒅 shooting -mek 𓁹 ⲙⲟⲛⲕ

The whole SA series is interchangeable
SA 𔗔 sa₁ 𔗦 sa₂ 𔑷 sa₃ 𔗆 sa₄ 𔕮 sa₅ 𔔀 sa₆ 𔕣 sa₇ 𔖮 -s ˢ ᵒˢ
-𔗔 -𔗦 -𔑷 -𔗆 -𔕮 -𔔀 -𔕣 -sa₁₂₃₄₅₆₇₈ /s/ -𐍃 nominative Ending 𐌱𐌰𐌲𐌼𐍃 Baǧms > Baumᵒˢ
-𔗔 -𔖪 -sa -za nominative/accusative singular neuter commonly followed by -sa -za

-𔗷𔗔 possessive/adjective s.o. inflects in agreement without plurality
-𔗷𔐤 -ana /-an/ is confined to adjectives in -𔗷𔓉 -asi (to avoid possessive confusion)
-𔐤 -na /-n/ accusative occasionally -𔕶 ná /n/ /un/
__ ablative does not show number

Comparison / Comparatives

-𔖱 -𔖲 -er high => higher 𓂋 tail 𓄢 𓄛 𓄜

𔐿𔑰𔖱 /(an)antara/ unter(e) "under/lower" (INFRA.ta.ra)
𔐣𔖱𔖩𔕷𔗬𔕬 𔐰𔓊𔖩𔓯 his younger brothers

Pronouns

𒉿𒉡 ᶜwa-nu ᶜwhence? +++
𒉿𒉡 whence? where?

kumanu "when" ⇔ comme "as"

𒂊𒉡𒈠 ᵏe-nu-ma 𓍿 𓈖 𓌙 𓅯 | whence | quand
𒂊𒉡𒈠 when

𒆪𒉿𒁉 • (ku-wa-pí) when where, *ku-wan-di:
conjunction Sumerogram when + Hittite phonetic complement ⇦an>... adverb; when, while adverb; when, where conjunction; when, where interrogative adverb; when, where conjunction; if, when conjunction if, when + locatival particle ⇦ssan> on, over adverb; as, how, when conjunction; as, how, when

𐋂 CARIAN LETTER ST Cζ
𐋃 CARIAN LETTER ST₂ Cζ ⇔ K@Hindu

The characters that are transliterated as -h- and -hh- have often been interpreted as pharyngeal fricatives [ħ] and [ʕ]. However, they may have instead been uvular [χ] and [ʁ] or velar fricatives [x] and [ɣ]. In loans to Ugaritic, these sounds are transcribed with <ḫ> and <ġ>, while in Egyptian they are transcribed with 𓐍 ḫ and 𓎼 g.[28] As both of these languages had pharyngeal consonants, the Luwian sounds are unlikely to have been pharyngeal.

A noteworthy phonological development in Luwian is rhotacism; in some cases, d, l, and n becomes r. For example, *īdi ('he gets') becomes īri and wala- '(die') becomes wara-.

𔖣 (U+145A3): This sign represents a quote marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is often used to indicate quoted speech or text.

𔓝 (U+143DD): This sign represents a name marker in the Anatolian Hieroglyphs script. It is used to mark names or titles of individuals.
